lines.text:
[speaking at the Old South church]
This meeting can do nothing more to save the country!

[riding through a town at night]
Turn out! Turn out your militia!

[opens window]
What's all the noise down there?
There's a time for casting silver and a time for casting cannon. If that isn't in the Holy Writ, it should be.

[speaking at meeting]
For we must fight this war, in meeting house and Congress and the halls of Parliament, as well as on the field! But what it's all about, you'll really never know. And yet it-it it's so much simpler than any of you think. We give all we have. We fight! We die, for a simple thing. Only that a man could stand.

[During the Tea Party]
Isn't it odd? These Indians seem to prefer principles to profits.
We'll stand by our orders, but if they mean to have a war, let it begin here.

[to his officers]
You see those campfires, gentlemen? Yesterday we ruled over Boston. Tonight we are beseiged in it. And still they come from every village and farm. Tonight 10,000. Tomorrow perhaps twice 10,000. We've experienced more than a defeat, more than a mere misfortune of war. We have been vanquished by an idea, a belief in human rights.
